metadata.title: 5 Things To Know: June 13, 2025
metadata.description: CNBC’s Becky Quick reports on the 5 things to know on June 13, 2025.

transcript.full_text: Five things to know ahead of today's opening bell. Israel striking Iran's nuclear infrastructure in a wave of attacks that Iran's elite Revolutionary Guard Corps said killed its top commander. Uh, Israel working to bring down drones that Iran launched in retaliation. Iran saying a key nuclear enrichment site was damaged, but that no radiation contamination has occurred. Investigators are searching the site of the airliner crash in Western India for evidence and missing people. Local media said one of the two black boxes from the Boeing 787 Dreamliner had been recovered, though that hasn't been confirmed. One passenger actually survived that crash. A federal appeals court ruling the Trump administration can maintain control of several thousand national guard troops in California and continue deploying them in Los Angeles. That order coming shortly after a lower court said that the National Guard deployment was illegal. The White House moved to deploy troops in response to protests over its immigration crackdown. And the house narrowly voting in favor of a proposal to cancel more than $9 billion in previously approved federal funding. More than $8 billion of that was earmarked for foreign aid. About a billion dollars was meant for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which funds PBS and NPR. And the New York Times reports that a group of venture capital firms are planning to buy about $250 million worth of shares of Elon Musk's artificial intelligence company, XAI. Documents seen by the paper say that employees could sell some of their shares in a tender offer that values XAI at about $113 billion.

Israel striking Iran's nuclear infrastructure in a wave of attacks that Iran's elite Revolutionary Guard Corps said killed its top commander. Uh, Israel working to bring down drones that Iran launched in retaliation. Iran saying a key nuclear enrichment site was damaged, but that no radiation contamination has occurred. Dreamliner had been recovered, though that hasn't been confirmed. One passenger actually survived that crash. A federal appeals court ruling the Trump administration can maintain control of several thousand national guard troops in California and continue deploying them in Los Angeles. That order coming shortly after a lower court said that the National Guard deployment was illegal. The White House moved to deploy troops in response to protests over its immigration crackdown. And the house narrowly voting in favor of a proposal to cancel more than $9 billion

in previously approved federal funding. More than $8 billion of that was earmarked for foreign aid. About a billion dollars was meant for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which funds PBS and NPR. And the New York Times reports that a group of venture capital firms are planning to buy about $250 million worth of shares of Elon Musk's artificial intelligence company, XAI. Documents seen by the paper say that employees could sell some of their shares in a tender offer that values XAI at about $113 billion.

analysis.summary:
Today's financial opening bell is preceded by several significant global events. In the Middle East, Israel has launched a series of strikes against Iran's nuclear infrastructure, which Iran's elite Revolutionary Guard Corps claims resulted in the death of its top commander. In response, Iran launched drones, which Israel is working to neutralize. Iran has confirmed damage to a key nuclear enrichment site but asserts no radiation contamination has occurred.

Simultaneously, an investigation is underway in Western India following an airliner crash. While local media reports indicate that one of the Boeing 787 Dreamliner's black boxes has been recovered, this remains unconfirmed. Notably, one passenger miraculously survived the crash.

Domestically, a federal appeals court has ruled in favor of the Trump administration, allowing it to maintain control and deployment of thousands of National Guard troops in California, specifically in Los Angeles. This ruling overturns a lower court's decision that had deemed the National Guard deployment illegal, a measure taken by the White House in response to immigration-related protests. Furthermore, the House of Representatives has narrowly passed a proposal to cancel over $9 billion in approved federal funding, with more than $8 billion allocated for foreign aid and approximately $1 billion intended for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which supports PBS and NPR.

In the tech sector, The New York Times reports that a consortium of venture capital firms intends to acquire approximately $250 million worth of shares in Elon Musk's artificial intelligence company, XAI. Documents reviewed by the newspaper reveal that employees will have the opportunity to sell some of their shares in a tender offer, valuing XAI at an estimated $113 billion.

key_points.text: Five key things to know ahead of today's opening bell were presented.
Israel carried out strikes against Iran's nuclear infrastructure.
The Israeli strikes were described as a wave of attacks.
Iran's elite Revolutionary Guard Corps stated its top commander was killed.
Israel is actively working to bring down drones launched by Iran.
Iran launched drones in retaliation to Israel's actions.
Iran reported that a key nuclear enrichment site sustained damage.
Iran claimed that no radiation contamination occurred at the damaged site.
Investigators are searching the site of an airliner crash in Western India.
The search at the crash site is for evidence and missing people.
Local media reported the recovery of one of two black boxes from the Boeing 787 Dreamliner.
The recovery of the black box from the airliner crash has not been officially confirmed.
One passenger survived the airliner crash.
A federal appeals court issued a ruling regarding the Trump administration.
The ruling allows the Trump administration to maintain control of National Guard troops.
Several thousand National Guard troops are located in California.
The Trump administration can continue deploying National Guard troops in Los Angeles.
The appeals court order came shortly after a lower court's ruling.
A lower court had previously declared the National Guard deployment illegal.
The White House moved to deploy troops in response to protests.
The protests were related to an immigration crackdown.
The House of Representatives narrowly voted on a proposal.
The proposal was to cancel previously approved federal funding.
More than $9 billion in federal funding was proposed for cancellation.
More than $8 billion of the cancelled funding was earmarked for foreign aid.
About $1 billion of the cancelled funding was intended for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
The Corporation for Public Broadcasting funds PBS.
The Corporation for Public Broadcasting funds NPR.
The New York Times reported on a group of venture capital firms.
Venture capital firms are planning to buy shares of Elon Musk's XAI.
The planned purchase involves about $250 million worth of XAI shares.
XAI is Elon Musk's artificial intelligence company.
Documents seen by The New York Times confirm the details.
XAI employees could sell some of their shares in a tender offer.
The tender offer values XAI at approximately $113 billion.

timeline_events.event_description: Introduction to daily news briefing 'ahead of today's opening bell'.
Israel strikes Iran's nuclear infrastructure in a wave of attacks.
Iran's elite Revolutionary Guard Corps reports its top commander was killed in Israeli attacks.
Israel works to bring down drones launched by Iran in retaliation.
Iran states a key nuclear enrichment site was damaged but no radiation contamination occurred.
Investigators search airliner crash site in Western India for evidence and missing people.
Local media reports one of two black boxes from the Boeing 787 Dreamliner recovered (unconfirmed).
One passenger survived the airliner crash.
Federal appeals court rules the Trump administration can maintain control of National Guard troops in California and continue deployments in Los Angeles.
A lower court previously ruled the National Guard deployment was illegal (this order came shortly before the appeals court ruling).
The White House deployed troops in response to protests over its immigration crackdown.
House narrowly votes in favor of a proposal to cancel over $9 billion in previously approved federal funding.
More than $8 billion of the canceled funding was earmarked for foreign aid.
About $1 billion of the canceled funding was meant for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
New York Times reports venture capital firms plan to buy $250 million worth of shares in Elon Musk's XAI.
Documents suggest employees could sell shares in a tender offer valuing XAI at $113 billion.

temporal_patterns.description: The report presents a daily news briefing structure, indicated by 'Five things to know ahead of today's opening bell', suggesting a recurring pattern of updates.

A causal chain of events regarding National Guard deployment: White House deployed troops -> lower court ruled deployment illegal -> appeals court ruled Trump administration can maintain control, with the appeals court ruling coming 'shortly after' the lower court.

A retaliatory sequence of events between Israel and Iran: Iran launched drones -> Israel working to bring down drones / Israel striking Iran's nuclear infrastructure (implied retaliation for drones or broader conflict).
